Q1:
Hey! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! So, over the next two weeks, I'll be checking out healthy and sustainable eating with you. üçé

Like, a year ago, I started eating more plant-based stuff and learned a bunch along the way. It's not about being perfect; I don't think we all need to go full vegan. But, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet, you know?

Stay tuned, 'cause I'll share lots of cool science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference. üí™
Q2: Fruits and veggies are packed with important stuff like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. Like I said, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. Every time we buy food, we decide what goes into our bodies. To make it fun, you could talk with your friends during lunch and try some plant-based foods together, you get my point?
Q3: Reducing meat we eat can save CO2, helps with climate change. Like if we eat meat every other day for a year, it's like driving from London to China and back! Small changes, everyone helps the environment. Let's start small, eat meat once a day, not breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has like the space of a laptop, hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase like Harry Potter your whole life. Factory farms keep going because we buy their products. If we choose to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we send a message for better living conditions, you get my point
Q5: Fiber is important for our stomachs, it's in plants not animal foods. When we have enough fiber, we stay full longer and more energy for school, no tired feeling after lunch. Changing habits like what we eat can be tricky. Easy way to start, try plant-based lunches at school, feel more energetic for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people say living sustainably is really important for happiness. And 77% like meat alternatives for that sustainable life. I mean it's good we agree on this. Even if we're not going full vegan, we can do something. Like trying those plant-based options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives, you get my point.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week. üå±

I like seeing more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! üçî

Why not see if some of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8:
Cutting down on meat, dairy, sugary stuff we eat can really help with acne, like up to 87% less acne in young people. Eating lots of veggies and fruits keeps skin hydrated, protects from sunburn, even stops wrinkles üçéü•¶

Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually get your food? Any tasty plant-based stuff you could try next time?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, CO2 from food would drop by 68%. Just by changing what we eat, we'd be halfway to stopping climate change. üåé

Climate change hits us young people the most, we'll see it in our lifetime. Instead of being all negative, let's find small changes we can do now. Choosing more plant-based stuff is an easy one.

You can also check which foods are bad for the climate, hint: the worst farm animal rhymes with 'wow'.
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives, never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, way less happy. We can't change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers instead of animal meat. It's the quickest way to help make animals' lives better, if you get my point.
Q11: Veggies and fruits got good stuff for our brains, makes it work better. Just add some more veggies, like three more each week, can boost mood, make us happier. No limit to plants we can eat, all good for brains! You could challenge yourself, friends, or parents, more plant-based meals some days, cheat day here and there. üçéü•¶
Q12: Animal farming is bad for Amazon, like 80% of loss is because of cattle and their food. Last year, Amazon lost lots of trees, like all trees in UK and Ireland together. Imagine no trees left! üå≥üå≥ By eating less meat, like veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference. If you eat with others, you can inspire them to be mindful too. I don't see the point of not trying.

Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learnt a lot along the way. Not about being perfect; don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. But being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, gonna share lots of interesting science facts and give u tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2:
So fruits and veggies are packed with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. Like, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.

Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, u could also chat with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together, mate.
Q3:
So reducing how much meat we eat can save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. Like if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!

With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small; like we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4:
So more than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms just to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for ur whole life.

Factory farms keep going cos people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals mate.
Q5:
So fiber is rly important for our stomachs, right? It's only in plants, not animal stuff. When we get enough fiber, we stay full longer and have more energy, no more tired after lunch.

Changing habits like what we eat can be tricky at first, mate. Maybe try more plant-based lunches at school, feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6:
So 80% of young ppl think living sustainably is v important for happiness. And 77% say they'd go for meat alternatives as part of that lifestyle.

Glad to see our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not going full vegan, we can all do something to help. Like trying plant-based options in our school cafeteria or meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey mate! Thanks for following along for the first week. 

I'm glad to see more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my fave celebs eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. 

I also notice new plant-based products and restaurants popping up everywhere. Looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! 

Just curious though, why not check if some of your fave celebs also eat plant-based?
Q8:
So cutting down on meat, dairy, and sugary stuff can like really help with acne, up to 87% less for young peeps. Plus, lots of veggies and fruits keep skin hydrated, protects from sunburn, and even stops wrinkles. 

Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. So when do u usually buy food in your day? Got any tasty plant-based stuff u could try next time?
Q9:
So if everyone ate less animal foods, CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people coz we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

U can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: So most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives, never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and scientists say much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better, mate.
Q11:
So veggies and fruits got these helpful plant stuff that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like 3 extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us happier.

No limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, u could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12:
So animal farming is why 80% of the Amazon rainforest is gone, coz they need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the Amazon lost like all the trees in the UK and Ireland together. Imagine if there were no trees left here! Just think about it.

By eating less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a diff without much effort. If u eat with others, u can set an example and inspire friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices too.

Q1:
Hi, I'm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, we'll explore healthy and sustainable eating together. üòä

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It's not about being perfect; I don't think we all need to go completely vegan. But, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I'll share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference. What about you? Have you tried plant-based foods?
Q2:
Hi, Panda. Fruits and vegetables are packed with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.

Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, what about trying out some plant-based foods with your friends during lunch?
Q3: Hi, reducing how much meat we eat can help save lots of CO2, which causes climate change. For instance, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China... and back! With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let's start small; for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner. What about you?
Q4: Hi, did you know more than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms just to keep animal products cheap? On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. Sad, isn't it? But these farms keep going because people buy their products. So, what about choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can? That way, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals. What do you think?
Q5:
Hi, Panda. Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch. What about you? Do you have enough fiber in your meals?

Changing our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon. What do you think?
Q6: Hi, did you know that 80% of young people believe living sustainably is very important for their happiness? And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle. It's great to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often. What about you?
Q7: Hi there! Thanks for following along for the first week. I'm excited to see more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! Why not see if some of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8:
Hi, reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne - up to 87% less acne in young people. Why not? Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.

Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. What about you? When do you usually buy food during your day? Do you have any tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9: Hi, Panda. If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change. It's sad, climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do. You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô). What about you?
Q10: Hi, did you know that most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight? It's sad, really. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But what about choosing more vegetables and meat alternatives? Like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers, you know? This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better. What do you think?
Q11: Hi, Panda. Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier. There's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there). What about you?
Q12:
Hi, Panda. Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!

What about you? By eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. Do you eat with others? You can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices as well. Mine as well. I'm trying to cut down on meat.

Climate change hits us young people the most, we'll see it in our lifetime. Instead of being all negative, let's find small changes we can do now. Choosing more plant-based stuff is an easy one.

You can also check which foods are bad for the climate, hint: the worst farm animal rhymes with 'wow'.
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives, never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, way less happy. We can't change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers instead of animal meat. It's the quickest way to help make animals' lives better, if you get my point.
Q11: Veggies and fruits got good stuff for our brains, makes it work better. Just add some more veggies, like three more each week, can boost mood, make us happier. No limit to plants we can eat, all good for brains! You could challenge yourself, friends, or parents, more plant-based meals some days, cheat day here and there. üçéü•¶
Q12: Animal farming is bad for Amazon, like 80% of loss is because of cattle and their food. Last year, Amazon lost lots of trees, like all trees in UK and Ireland together. Imagine no trees left! üå≥üå≥ By eating less meat, like veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference. If you eat with others, you can inspire them to be mindful too. I don't see the point of not trying.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along first week.

I'm excited to see more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It's looking like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

Cutting down on meat, dairy, sugary foods really helps with acne, like up to 87% less for young people. Lots of veggies and fruits keep skin hydrated, protect from sunburn, even stop wrinkles.

Most pigs, chickens in UK, they're indoors all their lives, never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside, more stressed, scientists say they're less happy.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.

Q1:
Hello Dreamy Sloth! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, we'll explore healthy and sustainable eating together. üéâ

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don't think we all need to go completely vegan. But being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet. üåø

Stay tuned, as I‚Äôll share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference. üí™
Q2: Woow, Fruits and vegetables are packed with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3:
Woow, reducing how much meat we eat can save loads of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!

With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small, for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Still on the game of saving our planet, yea?
Q4:
Woow, did you know more than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms just to keep animal products cheap? In these places, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life, how sad is that.

But these factory farms keep going because people buy their products. So, if we choose to eat less meat or go for plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals. Are you Aware of that?
Q5: Fiber is super important for our stomachs, you know, and it's only in plants, not animal stuff. When we get enough fiber, we stay full longer and have more energy for school, no more afternoon slumps! Changing what we eat can be tough, but hey, try plant-based lunches at school. You'll feel more ready for the afternoon, trust me!
Q6:
Woow, 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. AND 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.

It's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now, no need to wait for others! Let‚Äôs start small, like having meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4:
More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are stuck on factory farms just to keep animal products cheap. Its like, a chicken only gets the space of a laptop, hardly any room to move. Its like living under a staircase like Harry Potter, for your whole life, ya know?

These farms keep going cause people keep buying their stuff. But if we choose to eat less meat or try those plant-based ones when we can, we can tell them to make better lives for the animals.
Q5:
Fiber's really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and its only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.

Changing our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people reckon that living sustainably is really important for their happiness. And 77% say they'd go for meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle. It's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, we can all do our bit to help. Like, we can give the plant-based food in our school cafeteria a shot or try some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week. 

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. 

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It is exciting to think we'll have lots of options in the future! 

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: I feel reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne - up to 87% less acne in young people. I like that eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles. No, having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9: If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change. I feel climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do. You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK, they're kept indoors their whole lives, never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside, they're more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We can't change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives, like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers, instead of animal meat. It's the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have these helpful plant things that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies, like three extra servings each week, can already boost our mood and make us feel happier. No I feel there's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week, with an occasional cheat day here and there.
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest, you know? They need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here! It's crazy. But hey, by eating less meat, like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular ones for lunch, we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices as well. I feel it's important, don't you?

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants popping up everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! üå±

Why not check if some of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8:
Cutting down on meat, dairy, and sugary foods can really help with acne ‚Äì like, up to 87% less acne in young people! Eating lots of veggies and fruits keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from sunburn, and even stops wrinkles. ü•ó

Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If we all ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We might not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11:
Veggies and fruits have these amazing plant things that help our brains stay healthy and work really well. Just adding a few more veggies, like three extra servings each week, can boost our mood and make us feel happier. üòÉ

There's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! You could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest, because they need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here! Who else likes the idea of eating less meat? Like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch, we can make a difference without needing to change much. And if you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hey there! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, we‚Äôre going to explore healthy and sustainable eating together.

About a year ago, I started incorporating more plant-based foods into my diet and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. But, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we consume can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I‚Äôll be sharing lots of interesting science facts and giving you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2:
Fruits and vegetables are packed with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. Did you know that people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall?

Every time we buy food for ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, have you ever thought about talking with your friends during lunch and trying out some plant-based foods together?
Q3: You know, if we cut down on how much meat we eat, we can actually save a lot of CO2, which is a big deal for climate change. Like, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it's like driving a car from London to China and back! Crazy, right? So, why not start small? For example, we could try eating meat just once a day, instead of having it at every meal. It's these little changes that can really help the environment and slow down climate change. We don't have to wait for others to start making a difference!
Q4: You know, more than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms just to keep animal products cheap. In these places, a chicken only has about the space of a laptop, so there's barely any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your entire life. Factory farms keep going because we buy their products. But if we choose to eat less meat or go for plant-based options when we can, we can send a message to these farms to improve living conditions for their animals.
Q5:
You know, fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and you can only find it in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, so we can avoid that tired feeling after lunch. üòÑ

Changing our habits, like what we eat, can be a bit tricky at first. But an easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school. That way, you'll feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon. What do you think?
Q6: So, turns out 80% of young people think living sustainably is super important for their happiness. And get this, 77% say they'd go for meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle. It's amazing to see how much our generation is on the same page about this. Even if we're not going full vegan, each of us can do our part, you know? Like, we could try the plant-based options in our school cafeteria or swap in some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey there! Thanks for sticking around for the first week. üéâ

I'm really excited to see more and more people choosing to go plant-based. Some of my favorite celebs are vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. And then there are others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, who mostly avoid animal products.

Plus, I keep seeing new plant-based products and restaurants popping up everywhere. It's like we're going to have so many options in the future, you know?

Why not check if some of your favorite celebs are also into plant-based eating? ü§î
Q8: Did you know that cutting down on meat, dairy, and sugary foods can really help improve acne? Like, up to 87% less acne in young people! Plus, eating lots of vegetables and fruits keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from sunburn, and even stops wrinkles. Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. So, when do you usually do your food shopping? Are there any tasty plant-based options you could try next time you have a choice?

If everyone cut down on animal foods, we could drop CO2 from food production by 68%. Just by switching up our food choices, we'd be halfway to stopping climate change. üåø

Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.
